title: 5,200 Days in Space - The Atlantic
description: An exploration of life aboard the International Space Station, and the surprising reasons the mission is still worthwhile

title: What can meteorites tell us about life on and beyond Earth? | Aeon Essays
description: Could meteorites be akin to lifeboats from other planets? Or do they reveal more about life on Earth than off it?

title: Have We Already Been Visited by Aliens? | The New Yorker
description: Elizabeth Kolbert on an eminent astrophysicist who argues that signs of intelligent extraterrestrial life have appeared in our skies. What’s the evidence for his extraordinary claim?

title: Quanta Magazine
description: The James Webb Space Telescope has the potential to rewrite the history of the cosmos and reshape humanity’s position within it. But first, a lot of things have…

title: Chris Hadfield: in space 'you recognise the unanimity of our existence' | Space | The Guardian
description: He captured our imagination with a zero gravity cover of David Bowie's Space Oddity, but Chris Hadfield's time in space was a multi-facted, 'enriching' experience. The astronaut and Twitter phenomenon talks to Emma Brockes about the wonder of spacewalking and why he'll never look as good as Sandra Bullock in a spacesuit

title: Space Shuttle Columbia Disaster: Stranded in Space
description: In February 2003, after the explosion of the shuttle two American astronauts aboard the International Space Station suddenly found themselves with no ride home. And things got worse from there.

description: Xerox PARC, Apple, and the truth about innovation.

title: The World-Changing Race to Develop the Quantum Computer | The New Yorker
description: Such a device could help address climate change and food scarcity, or break the Internet, Stephen Witt writes. Will the U.S. or China get there first?

description: Internet at 40 In 1969 a student typed 'LO' on a computer - and the internet was born

title: Who Owns the Internet? | The New Yorker
description: What Big Tech’s monopoly powers mean for our culture.

title: Have Smartphones Destroyed a Generation? - The Atlantic
description: More comfortable online than out partying, post-Millennials are safer, physically, than adolescents have ever been. But they’re on the brink of a mental-health crisis.

description: Virginia Heffernan on why we all need to learn to read the internet, not live in it.

description: Adam Gopnik reviews some of the books that celebrate or censure the Internet, and considers what omnipresent information is doing to our minds.

title: Has technology set us free, or shackled us to our screens? | Aeon Essays
description: Gadgets are the first thing we touch in the morning and the last thing we stroke at night. Are we their slaves?

title: John Lanchester · You Are the Product: It Zucks!
description: I am scared of Facebook. The company’s ambition, its ruthlessness, and its lack of a moral compass scare me...

title: Does each click of attention cost a bit of ourselves? | Aeon Essays
description: It costs nothing to click, respond and retweet. But what price do we pay in our relationships and our peace of mind?

description: Angel the concierge stands behind a lobby desk at a luxe apartment building in downtown San Francisco, and describes the residents of this imperial, 37-story tower. “Ubers, Squares, a few Twitters,”…

title: Bloomberg - Are you a robot?
description: #ERROR

title: Soon We Won't Program Computers. We'll Train Them Like Dogs | WIRED
description: Welcome to the new world of artificial intelligence. Soon, we won't program computers. We'll train them. Like dolphins. Or dogs. Or humans.

title: Video Games Are Better Than Real Life
description: Many Americans have replaced work hours with game play — and ended up happier. Which wouldn’t surprise most gamers.

description: The new generation of video games including No Man's Sky and Grand Theft Auto attempts to give us what real life can't: endless possibility.

title: The stupidity of AI | Artificial intelligence (AI) | The Guardian
description: The long read: Artificial intelligence in its current form is based on the wholesale appropriation of existing culture, and the notion that it is actually intelligent could be actively dangerous

title: What Happens When an AI Knows How You Feel? | WIRED
description: Technology used to only deliver our messages. Now it wants to write them for us by understanding our emotions.

title: To understand AI sentience, first understand it in animals | Aeon Essays
description: As the power of AI grows, we need to have evidence of its sentience. That is why we must return to the minds of animals

title: The Untold Story of NotPetya, the Most Devastating Cyberattack in History | WIRED
description: Crippled ports. Paralyzed corporations. Frozen government agencies. How a single piece of code crashed the world.

title: The Confessions of Marcus Hutchins, the Hacker Who Saved the Internet | WIRED
description: At 22, he single-handedly put a stop to the worst cyberattack the world had ever seen. Then he was arrested by the FBI. This is his untold story.

title: The Enemy Within - The Atlantic
description: When the Conficker computer “worm” was unleashed on the world in November 2008, cyber-security experts didn’t know what to make of it. It infiltrated millions of computers around the globe. It constantly checks in with its unknown creators. It uses an encryption code so sophisticated that only a very few people could have deployed it. For the first time ever, the cyber-security elites of the world have joined forces in a high-tech game of cops and robbers, trying to find Conficker’s creators and defeat them. The cops are failing. And now the worm lies there, waiting …

title: Richard Clarke on Who Was Behind the Stuxnet Attack | Smithsonian
description: America's longtime counterterrorism czar warns that the cyberwars have already begun—and that we might be losing

title: The World of Internet Dating and Mating | The New Yorker
description: Nick Paumgarten on Internet dating, from its beginnings as computerized quizzes to its current incarnation in the form of apps and Web sites like Match.

title: Nintendo’s Guiding Spirit | The New Yorker
description: From 2010: Nick Paumgarten’s Profile of Shigeru Miyamoto, the man behind many of Nintendo’s best-known video games, including Mario and Donkey Kong.

title: Desert Bus: The Very Worst Video Game Ever Created | The New Yorker
description: Players earn a single point for each eight-hour trip, making a Desert Bus high score perhaps the most costly in gaming…

title: In the Next Industrial Revolution, Atoms Are the New Bits | WIRED
Mind Control & the Internet | Sue Halpern
description: A Google search ”curates” the Internet. It’s not just the large number of search variables, or the intervention of marketers, that shapes the information we’re shown by bringing certain pages to our attention while others fall...

description: The next generation of the Internet will rely on revolutionary new tech — allowing for unhackable networks and information that travels faster than the speed of light.

title: Streaming Dreams | The New Yorker
description: YouTube turns pro.

title: How Netflix Reverse-Engineered Hollywood - The Atlantic
description: To understand how people look for movies, the video service created 76,897 micro-genres. We took the genre descriptions, broke them down to their key words … and built our own new-genre generator.

title: What was twitter anyway?
description: Whether the platform is dying or not, it’s time to reckon with how exactly it broke our brains.

title: The Quantum Internet Will Blow Your Mind. Here’s What It Will Look Like | Discover Magazine
description: The next generation of the Internet will rely on revolutionary new tech — allowing for unhackable networks and information that travels faster than the speed of light.

title: That Way We’re All Writing Now. First we LOLed. Now we’re changing the… | by Clive Thompson | The Message | Medium
description: You’ve likely seen this style of writing all over the place — on Tumblr, Twitter, Snapchat, Yik Yak, or anywhere that people communicate in writing. It goes like this: Me—I’m in! Mind you, I’m a fan…

title: Inside Olympic Destroyer, the Most Deceptive Hack in History | WIRED
description: The untold story of how digital detectives unraveled the mystery of Olympic Destroyer—and why the next big cyberattack will be even harder to crack.

title: Russia's Cyberwar on Ukraine Is a Blueprint for What's to Come | WIRED
description: Blackouts in Ukraine were just a trial run. Russian hackers are learning to sabotage infrastructure—and the US could be next.

title: The "Vulkan Files": A Look Inside Putin's Secret Plans for Cyber-Warfare - DER SPIEGEL
description: Elite hackers from Russia have their sights set on airports and power plants around the world, along with the internet. Confidential data from Moscow, obtained by DER SPIEGEL and its partners, now provide a look inside their arsenal of cyber-weapons and reveal their strategy.

title: Welcome to the Dark Net, a Wilderness Where Invisible World Wars Are F | Vanity Fair
description: Through the eyes of a master hacker turned security expert, William Langewiesche chronicles the rise of the Dark Net—where weapons, drugs, and information are bought, sold, and hacked—and learns how high the stakes have really become.

title: Believable: The Terrifying Future Of Fake News
description: "What happens when anyone can make it appear as if anything has happened, regardless of whether or not it did?"

description: How teenage whiz kid Marcus Wanner set out to solve web mystery Cicada and found himself in a world of international intrigue.

description: #ERROR

title: Why Do We Care So Much About Privacy? | The New Yorker
description: Big Tech wants to exploit our personal data, and the government wants to keep tabs on us. But “privacy” isn’t what’s really at stake, Louis Menand writes.
